tJ’rqpoIogist must not , however, merely be a good guy; he must know when
to say no; when to insist on alteration; what is wrong with the anthro¬
pology in a script* He must also know the limits of his own responsibil¬
ity and not try to take over the functions of the writer or the producer*
This last is a recurrent temptation* There are many anthropologists who
can serve these functions better than I, and your problem is only to find
one and dislodge him from his prior commitments.
I would like to urge that, having found a suitable person, you
endeavor to give him as much freedom of action as you did me* lx you
have an anthropologist who fills the criteria of the preceding paragraph,
he will neither need nor properly respond to any strong limitations on
what he is to do. Give him the authority within the limitation of expecta¬
tion set by yourself; give him time, money and talent* This means that
you shouldn't have too specific a set of ideas as to what he will produce,
though you will want to set a general course of action. This can best be
done by finding an anthropologist who has a demonstrated interest in (or
even commitment to) the particular area of anthropology that you decide
you want*
I might offer some general suggestions as to what makes for good
radio shows* I personally followed the rule of being non-polemic * In¬
struction is better than preaching and in my opinion has a more moralis¬
ing effect*
Another general rule that X am fond of is that the general idea
should be the center of the show. The content, the particular culture
discussed, and the format are all servants to the idea, which is first to
be determined upon and delineated.
In this regard you will remember we engaged in an experiment for
the second series of the ”Ways of Mankind.” We tried to communicate the
total culture of lurok and Bali. I am not unhappy with these shows, but
I believe the experience demonstrates that it is better to concentrate
on an idea rather than to communicate a general area of involvement. A
culture, even a primitive one, is a large and complex: thing that cannot
be got in four shows or a dozen. Furthermore, one can never be sure of
carry-over from one week to the next. Listener experience may prove me
wrong, but my present feeling is that we are better advised to have
each show center on a concept, an idea or a closely associated set of
ideas•
As to content—we have barely scratched the surface of anthropol¬
ogy* If I were continuing, I would go back to my ^Memorandum of Basic
Plans” and follow its leads further—but perhaps I would just as lief
not see others doing it. Here are some suggestions of very different
kinds of programs that could be satisfactorily handled:
